ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Calculus
I learned a lot about calculus and techniques to better complete problems.
Continued knowledge on basic level calculus.
The most useful things I learned in this class were more methods of integration than I learned in high school and Taylor series.
Apart from learning new calculus techniques like integration, polar calculus, infinite series convergence/divergence, this course taught me to rely on my math textbook to learn.
I learned way to address difficult problem without excessive amounts of help.
Calculus skills, self-teaching skills, conceptual understanding vs memorizing skills
I learned valuable skills for integration and series that will really help me in any future courses I take that involve calculus.
I have learned to integrate relatively complex functions, compute infinite suites, and over get a better understanding of calculus.
I learned a lot about calculus.
I learned how to do calculus.
I strengthened skills in studying and review by taking this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We all receive the same exams but definitely do not receive the same quality of teaching. I found this to be very demoralizing and honestly just not fair.

This was the most boring class I have ever taken in my life. I dropped down from 120 so I have to blame myself a little bit for taking a class with material I already knew a lot of. Regardless, math has always been one of my favorite subjects since I was little and I still hated this class.
The explorations were not particularly useful. I prefer having concepts explained in class.

A strength of the class is the size of my class was not too large that it did not feel collaborative. Furthermore, my professor made extra effort to encourage student discussion. A way that it could be improved is to have worksheets given to all classes. In order to study for the final, I used worksheets that were handed out by Professor Diethorn to her students (I had access to them from my friend who is in her class). However, my class never received worksheets such as these.

This class was pretty standard in terms of math.  The amount of content covered was reasonable.

I think this class would have benefited greatly from a section.

Strengths: I think the structure of the explores and the weekly problem sets was good. I like how the units closely corresponded to the textbook sections.

Weaknesses: Sometimes I wish the problem sets were a LITTLE shorter/easier, but overall they were fine. I didn't understand the point of the Professor Demers activities -- they didn't add to my learning and I don't think they should be part of the course. My main issue with the class is that it needs to be more standardized across sections. Other people's teachers were making them review guides and giving them practice problems, while my teacher wasn't. In general, I feel that the course was not practice-based enough and we should have had more practice packets that we didn't have to submit as problem sets. The problems put up on the board during class that we were meant to discuss with neighbors were not sufficient.

I think a lot of time is spent on "fluff" that isn't really necessary. I wish more time was spent on Taylor series than a massive chunk of time on different ways to prove the divergence/convergence of a series

I believe the greatest strength for this course was the fact that they hosted review sessions each midterm as well as the final. The greatest weakness is that the quality of education varies greatly between professors. If it were up to me, I would make all of the MATH 115 professors use Professor Diethorns slides/review notes since those came in extremely useful!!
The teacher didnt always provide clear instructions on how problems were done.

I really liked the pre-class explores because it helped me understand each class' topic the first time around since I already had some familiarity with it (didn't have to go to office hours or consult textbook). I think there could have been more exam feedback.
I didn't really like the way collaboration was enhanced in the class, by working with the person sitting next to us.

A strength of this course is the vast amount of resources available to help a student if they are struggling. A weakness is that the time spent in class often feels wasted, due to the lack of direction.

The strengths and weaknesses varied a lot based on which instructor you had. In my case, I wanted more practice problems and application, whereas we only had a couple each class and the rest was spent with the instructor answering questions asked by peers and explaining concepts.
I personally had a lot of difficulty following my professor, and I wish there was more help offered from him.

A strength of this course was the resources available to students outside of class. One weakness of this course was the lack of testing skills (outside of exams). Additionally, there was a lack of in-depth lessons for new material. Oftentimes the course was hard to follow and connect each unit to an overall understanding of math.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, unless you need to take it or can guarantee you'll have a good section teacher.

It is a basic math class, so if you have to take it, take it. If it is optional for your major or you are looking to take a math class for fun (i.e. you already have your QR credits), I would absolutely not recommend taking it.
Yes, I would. The course has many resources both inside and outside of Yale to help students with the material.
I would reccomend taking this course, but I don't think my personal instructor was who would have worked best with me.
Yes but I would probably advise them against having my teacher.

If you're taking this course to get to higher level math, then definitely. If you enjoyed calculus in high school but all you want is a QR credit, I would still take it. I didn't find the course too difficult. If you hated calculus in high school and just need a QR credit, I might look somewhere else.

If youre in stem, youll most likely need to take this course so I say just get it over with. As someone who likes math it took some time to get used to the difference in teaching between high school and college but it was nonetheless interesting.
No
If you like math then yes. If you want or need a QR credit but do not need math then I would not recommend this course.
Yes, but I would recommend they choose their professor wisely.
Yes, I didn't know calculus before coming to university and now I feel that I have the knowledge to pursue higher level calculus classes or classes with more advanced math topics.
I would, because I think the content taught by this course is important.

If it's required for your major/track, then yes, you don't have much of a choice. I don't think it's necessary to take this course if you're not planning on going into a field that requires calculus/higher math. It wasn't a bad course by all means, I just felt like I did a lot of the learning on my own by solving p-sets and looking at example problems in the textbook.
If you have the right teacher, yes!

I would not recommend this course to students who have previously taken AP Calc AB, even if they placed into the class. Many people in my class tested down into MATH 115 instead of taking a higher level. This made the course speed challenging for students who did not test down and were learning the material for the first time.
